awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Model Theory of Differential and Difference Equations with Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is concerned with differential equations, which relate a quantity to its rate of change with respect to continuous time; difference equations, which relate a quantity to its rate of change with respect to discrete time; and combinations of these. Systems of such equations describe or model behavior and phenomena throughout the sciences; epidemiology, population dynamics, mechanics etc. The project will use methods from model theory, a branch of mathematical logic, to develop or improve procedures for showing consistency (existence of solutions) of systems of such equations, for identifying auxiliary parameters in systems of such equations, and for eliminating unknowns from such systems. The project will also extend the existing classification of sets of solutions from the case of over-determined (or finite-dimensional) systems to under-determined (or infinite-dimensional systems). 

In this focused research group project, the team of researchers studies differential, difference, and differential-difference equations, from the point of view of model theory in the sense of mathematical logic. Among the aims is to provide decision procedures or improve existing decision procedures regarding consistency and elimination. Applications to a variety of modelling problems for physical systems are expected. The proposed research is threefold. The first is to develop efficient algorithms in cases where the existing methods from theories of differential or difference fields provide algorithms in principle. The second is to extend the existing model-theoretic classification of finite-dimensional solution spaces of systems to infinite-dimensional solution spaces, as well as developing methods to apply the classification in practice. The third is to introduce and study new first order theories of rings with operators, whose decision procedures will apply to new examples arising in applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported joint work on the use of the model theory of differential and difference fields for their applications in the sciences.  Our most important results were the following.

  • Using ideas and methods from mathematical logic, specifically those having to do with canonical bases, canonical parameters, forking independence, and the like, from geometric stability theory, we built a deep theory of parameter identifiability for ODE models.  With these methods, we demonstrated that even when a model has been reduced so that there are no obviously extraneous parameters, contrary to what had been claimed in the literature, it is not always possible to compute the parameters from a single experient.  As a complement, we used these ideas to show that it is always possible to compute the parameters from the data of multiple independent experients.  We developed algorithms to implement these general results.
  • In practice, one seeks solutions to difference equations in sequence rings. Before our work, decision procedures for the solvability of systems of difference equations were known only when the solutions were sought in difference fields.  With this project, we produced an algorithm to determine solvability in sequence rings.  We extended this algorithm to one for determining the solvability of delay-differential equations.  As a complement, we established the undecidability of related problems for systems of difference equations involving multiple independent operators.
  • We developed the theory of difference and differential algebra to solve difficult open problems on functional transcendence and diophantine geometry over function fields.

This project directly supported the training of a diverse group of students and postdoctoral researchers in the mathematical sciences.
